title: For Sale/Trade:  Rare "Bring back" T56 1966 SKS
location: Fort Payne/Dekalb County, Alabama, United States
postcontent:
*SCROLL DOWN FOR SPECS AND BASIC DETAILS*

First off, I would like to state that I'm not positive that this is a bring back rifle as I have no certificate to prove so, I'm just somebody who got lucky on finding it and having the privilage of trying to figure it all out.

Some back story; I picked this rifle up from a friend a while back with the utmost intention of "fixing it up" (I thought it had just been left to rust in somebody's garage for a few decades, so I figured why not get a new project, right?). After receiving the rifle I noticed there were no import marks where they should be. After getting home and field stripping it, I scoured through every inch of the rifle and discovered no import marks anywhere on the gun. From then I then began the hunt for information on this piece.

First I searched how to figure out date on it, finding that serial numbers in the 10,000,000 are from 1966 production (This one is early 1966 - 101,4xx,xxx) I knew where to  start from. After that I searched for more details on that production year, and here's what I found so far; The receiver is pre 1966 type since it doesn't match the post 1965 designs (Possibly made before they integrated the next design). Next I found out that it had an older bayonet lug and front sight variant for blade types, which is odd because 1966 is when they switched to spike bayonets, funnily enough the stock is a 1964 type with a spike cut out. Also among other things the barrel lug matches with 1966 production, and the stock retainer has a blade cut instead of spike. In all it's kind of an odd combo of parts if you really think about it, but then again at a turn or change of production pieces there could be a mix of parts.

After finding out everything I did, at that point I started focusing on the stock which was refinished by my friend (Sanded, steamed, and coated with polyurethane sadly). I toyed with the idea of stripping it and trying to restore it and get back an "original battlefield" look for coolness, but after looking at it under light I discovered what looked like carvings on the left side above the magazine area. Out of everything, all I can make out is Live/Love, SWOEO, and "thy", I'm really not sure if this would be something from a GI, but it's interesting either way.


I took it to my local gun shop owner who is a Vietnam Veteran to get a second opinion and he agreed with the idea that it's a bring back and could possibly have been one that a soldier threw in to his rucksack after recovering it from a battle or "lifting" it from elsewhere. He couldn't say for certain if it was, even though he's seen many that have looked the same. But regardless of thoughts and ideas, what is for certain is that there's no import mark or marks and also the fact that the stock is extremely worn from use, both of which have lead me to believe that there's at least maybe an 70% chance of it being a battlefield, rathole, or "other" capture/pick-up.
